statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
Earl Boykins put on another amazing show with a career-high 28 points
and eight assists as the Warriors beat the Minnesota Timberwolves
107-98 on Friday night.
article.headline: Five-foot-5 Boykins scores career-high 28
article.linkText: Boykins stands tall in Warriors' win over T-Wolves
article.story:
OAKLAND, Calif. (AP) -- Whenever the NBA's shortest player is on his game, no opponent seems too tough at home for the Golden State Warriors.
Boykins

Earl Boykins put on another amazing show with a career-high 28 points and eight assists as the Warriors beat the Minnesota Timberwolves 107-98 on Friday night. The 5-foot-5 Boykins scored 20 points in the fourth while exasperating Minnesota with his usual array of feathery jumpers, daredevil drives and clever passes. The Arena crowd's favorite player got too many standing ovations to count while dominating the quarter. The Timberwolves, who became the seventh contender to get beaten in Oakland this season by the perennially losing Warriors, wanted to stand and applaud as well. "He totally changed the whole entire game,'' Wally Szczerbiak said. "We didn't know what to do. He took us all by surprise. He was getting wherever he wanted to go on the court. We had no answer for him whatsoever.'' Antawn Jamison scored 23 points, and Gilbert Arenas had 16 points, 10 rebounds and nine assists for the Warriors, who made a 21-8 run in the fourth quarter that was fueled by Boykins' ability to run past Minnesota point guards Rod Strickland and Igor Rakocevic. "I knew that Rod was getting tired, and when they went to a big lineup, they didn't have a guy in there who was used to checking a point guard,'' Boykins said. "I knew I could get in the paint. ... When they brought Igor in there, you could see the guy was nervous, so I went at him, just like people go at me.'' The Warriors are 8-4 since Christmas, and Boykins deserves much of the credit for energizing his teammates and providing steady scoring. Boykins surpassed his career high of 23, set last month against Dallas. "Too much Earl Boykins,'' Minnesota coach Flip Saunders said. "He changed the whole tempo of the game when he came in. He beat our pick-and-rolls, he split us on traps, found open guys, scored and just did a good job.'' Kevin Garnett scored 22 points for the Timberwolves, who haven't won three straight all season. Minnesota's eighth two-game winning streak of the season was snapped, as was its three-game winning streak against Golden State. After claiming the lead in the third, Golden State went up by 11 early in the fourth and kept stretching it thanks to Boykins, who was in virtuoso form. With a raucous ovation accompanying each shot, he drove the lane for a high-arching layup, scored twice from the perimeter and floated a jumper over the entire Minnesota frontcourt in the first two minutes alone. "He draws so much attention and finds those open guys, but it was a team effort,'' Jamison said. "We're maturing, and we're taking steps forward.'' Kendall Gill had 14 points for the Timberwolves, who had won four of their previous five. Six Minnesota players scored in double figures, but the Wolves made 20 turnovers and got outrebounded 49-32 by the NBA's best rebounding team. Garnett scored 14 points in the first quarter on 6-of-7 shooting, and Minnesota led by 11 early in the second before Boykins and Jamison led Golden State on a 10-2 run to close the half. Warriors reserve Bob Sura got ejected early in the second quarter for staring down referee Steve Javie after a no-call, then kicking a hole in an illuminated advertisement for the team's flagship radio station on the scorers' table. Sura also knocked over a folding chair on his way to the locker room. Golden State's Jason Richardson and Troy Murphy also got quick technical fouls from the notoriously short-tempered Javie and his crew. Game notes
Murphy kept alive his streak of starting in every game this season despite a big bruise on his right leg. Golden State has used the same starting lineup in all 39 games this season. ... Troy Hudson missed his second straight game for Minnesota with a sprained ankle. Strickland started in his place, getting 10 points, six assists and four turnovers.
